issue.title: OQS Enabled Envoy Contribution
issue.body:
We would like to contribute a compiled and functional fork of envoy v1.23.1 enabled with post-quantum encryption.

The source code repository can be found [here](https://github.com/Post-Quantum-Mesh/envoy-oqs). In the README, build instructions and a docker image are also listed. Three of the example demos that were provided with the original envoy source code have been modified to use the post-quantum implementation. They can be found in the examples folder in the source directory.

In order to make this work, I forked the OpenQuantumSafe implementation of BoringSSL, and updated the master-with-bazel branch to compile the latest BSSL code. This is stored [here](https://github.com/Post-Quantum-Mesh/boringssl).

We will be presenting this project, plus a post-quantum enabled istio build, at [KubeCon](https://kccncna2022.sched.com/event/182KF) on October 28th. As part of the presentation, we will be inviting the open-source community to continue work on the envoy and istio projects.

Please let me know if it would be OK to submit a pull request for the boringssl fork to the bssl-oqs repo and the envoy demo to the oqs-demos repo, and do not hesitate to e-mail me with any questions or comments.

Thank you very much,

Daniel Rouhana
danielrouhana@pm.me

comment.body: Thanks again for the contribution! Issue closed as #161 has merged.

issue.title: OQS Enabled Envoy Contribution
issue.body:
I hope I have checked all the boxes in the contribution guide.

Thank you!

Daniel

comment.body: @drouhana Did you see the question above? Any quick thoughts? Sensible or hopeless/too much effort? If the former, could you point to the binaries that need replacement so I could try this if you don't have the time?

issue.title: Update README.md
issue.body:
In order to install liboqs-python I needed to install this package in order to run setup.py on my Mac M1

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Just to be clear, shall I create a requirements.txt file and push all the packages to install liboqs-python there instead?

comment.body:
> shall I create a requirements.txt file 

that would be great -- maybe showing in the text how to use it

> and push all the packages to install liboqs-python there instead?

Now I'm surprised: Are there more packages needed than `setuptools` to run `python3 setup.py install`? I'd have thought all that's missing on https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python/blob/main/README.md is a hint to pip3-install `setuptools` prior to running the install command (or utilize the new requirements.txt in it) . Am I wrong there?

comment.body: The reason I thought about using a `requirements.txt` was to combine the other packages required to install liboqs (i.e.,  `pip3 install pytest pytest-xdist pyyaml` from the liboqs README). But yeah it might be easier to just edit the python-liboqs README and add a line to install `setuptools` for MacOS, does that work?

comment.body:
> does that work?

For me, sure it does/would (Thanks in advance!). 

Just in case you'd feel like contributing more, have a look at https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python/issues/57 (and pardon any possible "obviousness": I'm not a "pythonist").

issue.title: Enable access to the curves and certificate type
issue.body:
This PR changes enable access to the curves and certificate type used in TLSv1.1 handshakes.

This equivalent to access to the ciphers used in the TLS session. The benefit is that monitoring/logging can not only report the protocol and ciphers, but also the curve and certificate type used for a TLSv1.1 connection on the client side. In particular, an user can verify that a quantum-safe-crypto curve and certificate was used.

<!--
Thank you for your pull request. Please review these requirements:

Contributors guide: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING

Other than that, provide a description above this comment if there isn't one already

If this fixes a github issue, make sure to have a line saying 'Fixes #XXXX' (without quotes) in the commit message.
-->

##### Checklist
<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->
- [x] documentation is added or updated
- [ ] tests are added or updated

comment.body: Thanks for this contribution! Your comment above confuses me a bit, though: The PR code does not look TLSv1.1 specific. Also, the OQS-enablement only works for TLSv1.3. Lastly, do you intend to add some example/test code, too?

comment.body: Oh, yes.  That's my mistake.  I meant V1.3.  I looked for the tests of `ssl3_ctrl` function but I couldn't.  Would you tell me where the other tests are.  I want to add tests for these functions.

issue.title: Question: Worth while automating install?
issue.body:
Triggered by https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1367 this is to ask whether it might be worth while extending `setup.py` along the lines shown e.g., [here](https://github.com/pybind/cmake_example/blob/master/setup.py) to build `liboqs` automatically when running the install (e.g., after making `liboqs` a git submodule of `liboqs-python`)? Have you already considered this once, @vsoftco ?
Right now, running `python3 setup.py install` runs successfully even if liboqs has not been built (and/or is not on `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`) -- "just" the subsequent commands then don't work: At least confused me somewhat -- but then again, I'm no serious python user...
